Yes, there are several challenges that the efforts to preserve the purity of the Tamil language face. One of the main challenges is the widespread use of English and other languages in various domains such as education, media, and administration. This has led to a situation where many Tamil speakers, especially those who are educated or live in urban areas, use a significant number of loanwords from other languages in their speech and writing.

Another challenge is the fact that many Tamil speakers themselves may not be familiar with classical Tamil or even the purest form of modern Tamil. The ordinary people's language may have evolved to include loanwords from other languages, and they may not even recognize these words as being foreign. This makes it challenging to raise public awareness about the importance of preserving the purity of Tamil language.

Finally, there is a concern that the emphasis on preserving the purity of the Tamil language may exclude or marginalize people who do not speak standard Tamil, such as those who speak dialects of Tamil or other regional languages. Therefore, it is important to strike a balance between preserving language purity and promoting linguistic diversity and inclusion.
